channel.description: The latest news from LA Daily News: http://sstapleton-development.mn1.dc.publicus.com website: all stories : extended version

item.title: Three men convicted of 2010 murder in Long Beach
item.description:
LONG BEACH >> Three men are awaiting sentencing after being convicted this week of murder for the 2010 death of a 33-year-old Lake Elsinore man, authorities said Friday.

On Wednesday, after a six-week trial, Luis Orozco of Norwalk, Shawn Verette of Bellflower and Frank Ervin of Compton were all found guilty of the murder of Franklin Robles.
item.dc:creator:
By Joe Segura


joe.segura@presstelegram.com @JoeSeguraPT on Twitter

item.title: Russia a protector of human rights? Nyet
item.description:
The world is left to wonder about Edward Snowden's choice of a country to seek and accept temporary asylum.

Snowden, the former National Security Administration contractor who revealed the extent of U.S. monitoring of its citizens' phone records and Internet usage, is a self-styled advocate for human rights.
item.dc:creator: Los Angeles News Group opinion staff

item.title: Need an altitude adjustment? Head to Big Bear Lake
item.description:
BIG BEAR LAKE>> There's been a lot of construction activity in the Village here, the commercial and tourist center of this alpine getaway in the San Bernardino Mountains.

There was some concern over the disruption to local businesses, but so far everyone seems to be coping pretty well.

item.title: TRAVEL: The royal treatment in Scotland
item.description:
You can vicariously live like a king or queen by visiting two royal residences in Edinburgh, because the capital of Scotland is home to both a palace and a castle.

Of course, when you look back at history, living like a Royal may lose its appeal.

By the time Mary, Queen of Scots, was executed at age 44, she had been married and widowed three times and had given birth to the future king of England and Scotland.
item.dc:creator: By Karen E. Weber karen.weber@sgvn.com

media:content.media:description: Heraldic panel at Holyrood includes a unicorn and thistles, two symbols of Scotland.
Holyrood Palace and fountain.

St. Margaret's Chapel in Edinburgh Castle, is the oldest surviving building in Edinburgh, Scotland.

OLYMPUS DIGITAL CAMERA
Edinburgh Castle. Looking down at the Redcoat Cafe, left, and the One O'Clock Gun (the long one at right).

item.title: Logan Lerman returns as Percy Jackson in 3-D 'Sea of Monsters' movie
item.description:
"You mean when I was a prop?" deadpans Logan Lerman.

The subject is just how young the star of the 3-D "Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters" was when he started acting. He was 7, by the way, when he filmed "The Patriot," playing one of Mel Gibson's character's sons.
item.dc:creator: Rob Lowman

item.title: Shark week on the Discovery Channel has a mix of real-life and movie shark attacks
item.description:
"It's not a tiger shark"

"How do you know that?

"Shark Week."

- an exchange in "Sharknado," the cheesy Syfy Channel movie that recently became a Twitter-fed cultural sensation.

By Rob Lowman

robert.

item.title: Retired officer's motorcycle clipped by driver at HBO shoot in North Hollywood
item.description:
NORTH HOLLYWOOD -- A woman suspected of driving under the influence was in custody Friday morning after she clipped the motorcycle of a retired Los Angeles police officer providing traffic control at an HBO film shoot in North Hollywood, authorities said.

The retired officer was not injured in the crash, which happened around 11:15 p.

item.title: Palmdale: Have you seen these men who assaulted, robbed 19-year-old outside 7-Eleven
item.description:
PALMDALE -- Authorities today were seeking the public's help in locating five assailants who robbed a man outside a 7-Eleven in Palmdale.

The robbery happened around 1:10 a.m. Monday in the 700 block of East Palmdale Boulevard, said Deputy Jodi Wolfe of the sheriff's Palmdale Station.

media:content.media:description: This is a surveillance image from the 7-Eleven in the 700 block of East Palmdale Boulevard of one of the suspects in the early-morning July 29, 2013 assault and robbery of a 19-year-old outside the convenience store.

This is a surveillance image from the 7-Eleven in the 700 block of East Palmdale Boulevard of one of the suspects in the early-morning July 29, 2013 assault and robbery of a 19-year-old outside the convenience store.

This is a surveillance image from the 7-Eleven in the 700 block of East Palmdale Boulevard of one of the suspects in the early-morning July 29, 2013 assault and robbery of a 19-year-old outside the convenience store.

This is a surveillance image from the 7-Eleven in the 700 block of East Palmdale Boulevard of one of the suspects in the early-morning July 29, 2013 assault and robbery of a 19-year-old outside the convenience store.

item.title: New L.A. Councilwoman Nury Martinez: Let's get more women running for office
item.description:
VAN NUYS -- The Los Angeles City Council once again has a female member, thanks to today's swearing-in of newly elected Nury Martinez.

The results of the July 23 special run-off election, in which Martinez edged out front-runner Cindy Montanez, were affirmed on a 14-0 vote of the council.
item.dc:creator: City News Service

media:content.media:description: L.A. City Councilwoman Nury Martinez

item.title: 'A really nice guy': Canoga Park father, 23, killed in Sun Valley pot-shop burglary
item.description:
SUN VALLEY -- Authorities today released the name of a man who was shot and killed during a confrontation with several other men who apparently were burglarizing a marijuana collective in Sun Valley.

The shooting happened around 11:30 p.m. Tuesday in the 8200 block of Lankershim Boulevard, police said.
item.dc:creator: City News Service

item.title: It's Out of the Question: A-Rod has options, but none of them very good
item.description:
What sensible choices are left at this point for role model/ centaur model/ Damned Yankee Alex Rodriguez before the weekend, and possibly his career, comes to a darkening close?

He could do the half-manly (and half-equine) thing and admit his biogenetic guilt, then attempt to flex his plea bargaining skills while seeking asylum in a Moscow, Idaho airport.
item.dc:creator: Tom Hoffarth

item.title: Time Warner Cable drops CBS in NY, LA, Dallas
item.description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Three million Time Warner Cable customers in New York, Los Angeles and Dallas lost access to CBS programming in a fee dispute Friday, threatening their ability to watch popular shows like "Under the Dome" or see Tiger Woods pursue his 8th win at the Firestone Country Club.
item.dc:creator: RYAN NAKASHIMA AP Business Writer

media:content.media:title: CBS off the air in L.A.

media:content.media:description: This image provided by CBS shows a CBS advertisement in Times Square in New York on Friday. Three million Time Warner Cable customers in New York, Los Angeles and Dallas lost access to CBS programming in a fee dispute Friday.

item.title: Art show to celebrate Reseda's rock 'n' history
item.description:
RESEDA >> Sal Guitarez didn't have a darkroom when he was house photographer for the Reseda Country Club some 30 years ago. So he made proof sheets from his home's darkened kitchen and printed the photos of the club's legendary performers that seemed the most promising.

Guitarez, himself a musician, took thousands of shots of rock 'n' roll greats performing there between 1981 and 1984 including Chuck Berry, B.
item.dc:creator: Brenda Gazzar

media:content.media:description: Artist Levi Ponce works on a mural outside Continental Art Supplies in Reseda, CA. This Saturday, the Reseda Neighborhood Council, in partnership with Continental Art Supplies and 11:11, a creative collective presents 'Reseda', an art show in celebration of Reseda's legendary Rock þÄòn Roll history. The show can be viewed from 6-9 PM July 3rd at Continental Art Supplies.(Andy Holzman/Los Angeles Daily News)

item.title: School funding and flexibility key to California's success: Editorial
item.description:
Just like students returning to class this fall, backpacks filled with pencils, erasers, notebooks and other tools to support their learning, California schools start the 2013-14 year with extra supplies meant to improve academic achievement.

Thanks to the November passage of Proposition 30, schools throughout California will see increases in funding that many hope will help the state climb the ranks of per-pupil funding nationwide and, along the way, give the state's students a leg up on academic performance indicators.

item.title: Strip club faces possible shutdown
item.description: Los Angeles police are looking to shut down a strip club and bar complex in Canoga Park they say has become a nuisance and a magnet for crime, attracting complaints of prostitution, assaults and other incidents on the property.The Xposed Gentleman's Club at 8237 Canoga Ave. is part of a building that includes an adjoining bikini bar serving alcohol called the Wet Spot.
item.dc:creator: By Kelly Goff kelly.goff@dailynews.com @KellyGoff_DN on Twitter

media:content.media:description: Xposed on Canoga Avenue, south of Roscoe Boulevard. Thursday, August 1, 2013. (Michael Owen Baker/L.A. Daily News)

item.title: Question of the Week: Are Anthony Weiner and Bob Filner and their ilk politically redeemable?
item.description:
We asked readers, are Anthony Weiner and Bob Filner and their ilk politically redeemable?

Behavior speaks volumes about true character

Are we supposed to believe that schizophrenic-type behavior is acceptable among our politicians? That aberrant behaviors are only employed in their private life? That these same behaviors aren't reflected in the job they are supposed to do while in office? That they are able to serve in the best interests of the United States and its citizens, but still act like jerks in private?

It should be obvious this is not working.

item.title: Double-decker tour bus wedged on canyon road in Malibu
item.description: The City of Malibu advises that a double-decker tour bus has become stuck on a narrow, winding dead-end mountain road in Malibu. The bus is wedged on Carbon Canyon Road north of Pacific Coast Highway, and the city estimates it will be there 2-4 hours.
item.dc:creator: City News Service

item.title: What kind of living do businesses owe their employees? RedBlue America
item.description: A new phenomenon has spread across the nation in recent weeks: "Fast food strikes," named for the restaurant chain workers who have walked off the job in several cities, saying that establishments like Burger King and McDonald's don't pay employees enough to make ends meet.

item.title: Joan Jett kicks off Sunset Strip Music Festival, 'Goddess of Rock' named 2013 honoree
item.description:
In 1981, Joan Jett got Los Angeles to scream: "I love rock 'n' roll!"

More than three decades later, Los Angeles showed that they love her, too, by giving her a coveted music award.

"It's surreal. I left L.A. with a very bitter taste in my mouth," Jett said, referring to the nearly two dozen rejections she got from Los Angeles record labels before hitting it big in the music scene.
item.dc:creator: Mariecar Mendoza

media:content.media:title: Joan Jett at House of Blues

media:content.media:description: Joan Jett and the Blackhearts show at the House of Blues as part of the Sunset Strip Music Festival, Thursday, August 1, 2013. (Michael Owen Baker/L.A. Daily News)

item.title: LAUSD offers free vaccines at school-based clinics
item.description:
Los Angeles Unified is hosting free immunization clinics before school starts on Aug. 13 to help incoming seventh-graders comply with state law requiring them to show proof of a whooping cough vaccine.

The Tdap booster will be administered from 7:30 a.m.-2:30 p.m next Monday through Friday at the North Area Nursing Office, 6505 Zelzah Ave.
item.dc:creator: Barbara Jones

media:content.media:description: Linda McClellan preps a Tdap vaccine for Zalel Dursun during a Columbus Middle School clinic on Aug. 2, 2013. (Barbara Jones/Los Angeles Daily News)

item.title: News and events from Los Angeles Daily News reporters
item.description: News and events reported by Los Angeles Daily News reporters via social media.

item.title: Religion calendar in the San Fernando Valley
item.description:
Shabbat in the Park: Various San Fernando Valley Jewish congregations collaborate on the service, 6:15 p.m. today. Activities, including a drum circle, 5 p.m.; concert, 7:15-8 p.m. Bring your own dinner and lawn seating. Warner Center Park, 5800 Topanga Canyon Blvd., Woodland Hills. 818-348-0670.

The Acorn Principle at Center for Spiritual Living-Westlake Village: Jim Cathcart presents a program on "Intelligent Motivation," 1 p.

item.title: California should fix its broken ESL programs: Sean Kennedy
item.description: With more than 6 million California adults - mostly immigrants - adults lacking adequate English skills, the state doesn't need another blue ribbon panel. The state needs to repair the broken system that is meant to teach immigrants English, the real key to unlocking the American dream.
item.dc:creator: By Sean Kennedy

item.title: Russian a protector of human rights? Nyet
item.description:
The world is left to wonder about Edward Snowden's choice of a country to seek and accept temporary asylum.

Snowden, the former National Security Administration contractor who revealed the extent of U.S. monitoring of its citizens' phone records and Internet usage, is a self-styled advocate for human rights.

item.title: August celebrates the best thing since sliced bread
item.description:
David Weisberg, co-owner of Cavaretta's Italian Deli, estimates the Canoga Park landmark whips up as many as 500 sandwiches a day.

Just imagine, then, how many meatball subs and classic Italian heroes the busy counter crew will crank out in August, aka National Sandwich Month. Or how many Weisberg himself has made since he started doing prep work at the deli in 1985.
item.dc:creator: Barbara Jones

media:content.media:description: Blair Emole makes a sandwich during National Sandwich Month at Cavarettas Deli in Woodland Hills, CA. 8/1/2013(John McCoy/LA Daily News)

item.title: X Games thrill, but about to leave sad fans behind
item.description:
Teenager Isabel Serna was thrilled to be at Staples Center for the X Games with her sister by her side and a cap turned fashionably askew.

She had motocross racing on her mind Thursday and couldn't wait to check out her favorite riders, Jeremy Stenberg and Josh Hansen.

Her mood turned sad only when talk of the X Games moving to Austin, Texas next year came up in conversation.

media:content.media:description: Alana Smith competes during the X Games Los Angeles Women's Skateboard Street Final at LA Live Thursday, August 1, 2013. (Hans Gutknecht/Los Angeles Daily News)

item.title: President Obama to return to L.A. - and Leno
item.description:
President Obama returns to California next week for a two-day trip in a swing through western states that will include another appearance on "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno."

White House spokesman Jay Carney said in a press briefing that the president will first go to Phoenix to talk about how his economic proposals will help the middle class by investing in manufacturing and infrastructure.

media:content.media:description: In this July 30, 2013, photo, President Barack Obama walks from Marine One, across the South Lawn of the White House to the Oval Office in Washington, as he returns from Chattanooga where he spoke about the middle class and the economy. There's a new cadence to President Barack Obama's musings about Congress: Why canít House Republicans be more like their mates in the Senate? As Obama presses his economic agenda across the country, heís playing one chamber against the other, hoping Americans will hear his calls for compromise and conclude itís not his fault almost nothing is getting done in Washington. (AP Photo/Carolyn Kaster)

item.title: DWP bows to political pressure
item.description:
Bowing to political pressure, the head of the Department of Water and Power this week ordered a dramatic change in how sick leave is accrued and paid out to the utility's workers.

General Manager Ron Nichols sent out a memo on Wednesday instituting a change requiring workers to provide a note from a doctor if they are sick for more than three days.
item.dc:creator: Rick Orlov

item.title: Judge orders trial in Northridge boardinghouse killings
item.description:
A judge has ordered the man accused of killing four people outside a Northridge boardinghouse last year to stand trial for the murders.

San Fernando Superior Court Judge Harvey Giss listened to three days of witness testimony during a preliminary hearing for Ka Pasasouk, 31, who stands accused of shooting two women and two men in the early-morning hours of Dec.
item.dc:creator: By Kelly Goff kelly.goff@dailynews.com @KellyGoff_DN on Twitter

item.title: Castaic boy, 8, remains hospitalized after father found him in filled washing machine
item.description:
CASTAIC -- An 8-year-old boy was hospitalized today after his father found him unconscious in a water-filled washing machine at their Castaic home, authorities said.

Detectives from the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Special Victims Bureau were investigating the injury, which happened around 7:30 p.

item.title: LITTLE LEAGUE: Chino National remains unbeaten in Senior tournament
item.description:
ONTARIO >> The Chino National all-star team improved to 3-0 on Thursday with a 2-1 victory over Washington in the Little League Senior Western Regional held at Jay Littleton Ballpark.

The winner of the tournament advances as the West Region representative to the Senior Little League World Series held in Bangor, Maine on Aug.
item.dc:creator: By Jason Nowa Correspondent

item.title: LITTLE LEAGUE: Western Regional tournament and teams at a glance
item.description: Where: 6707 Little League Drive, San Bernardino Who: 12 teams from 11 states, six teams in each the West and Northwest Regions What: Winner from each region advances to Little League World Series When: Pool play games Friday, Aug. 2 through Wednesday, Aug. 7 at 9 a.m., 11:45 a.m., 5 p.m. and 8 p.

item.title: Live updates: Little League Baseball Western Regional in San Bernardino
item.description: Live score reports, photos, galleries, video and stories throughout the 2013 Western Regional Little League tournament in San Bernardino, Aug. 3 to Aug. 10.

media:content.media:description: Game action between Alaska, of Abbott-O-Rabbit LL, and Washington, of Eastlake LL, in the Little League Baseball Northwest Regional Tournament in San Bernardino on Friday, Aug. 2, 2013. Washington defeated Alaska 10-2. (Rachel Luna / Staff Photographer)

item.title: X GAMES: Eliot Sloan wins Skateboard Big Air
item.description:
IRWINDALE >> Eliot Sloan won the X Games Skateboard Big Air competition by a nose on Thursday evening at Irwindale Speedway.

The Vista resident, who turns 26 on Monday, got the gold medal in the death-defying event when favorite Bob Burnquist took a nasty fall and broke his nose during the competition on the mega ramp.
item.dc:creator: By Keith Lair Staff Writer

media:content.media:description: Watchara Phomicinda???Staff Photographer
Watchara Phomicinda???Staff Photographer

Elliot Sloan falls during the America's Navy Skateboard Big Air final during X Games Los Angeles at Irwindale Event Center in Irwindale on Thursday, August 1, 2013. (SGVN/Staff photo by Watchara Phomicinda)

item.title: Candidates line up to succeed Bonnie Lowenthal and Isadore Hall in California Assembly
item.description:
With term limits forcing Democrats Bonnie Lowenthal and Isadore Hall out of office next year, a raft of candidates -- some with big money already in hand -- is lining up to replace the veteran state Assembly members in 2014.

Lowenthal, whose 70th District includes San Pedro and Catalina Island, and Hall, whose 64th District includes Carson and Rancho Dominguez, are both in their third and final terms in office.
item.dc:creator: By Eric Bradley and Andrew Edwards, Staff Writers

item.title: South Bay, Harbor Area hospitals ranked in surgical safety
item.description:
A first-of-its-kind national analysis by Consumer Reports ranks Providence Little Company of Mary Medical Center in Torrance as the safest hospital for surgery among South Bay and Harbor Area hospitals.

Little Company earned a safety score of 55 out of 100 -- a grade that combines such measures as patient outcomes (including infections, readmissions and complications), patient experiences and hospital practices.
item.dc:creator: By Kristin S. Agostoni and Susan Abram, Staff Writers

item.title: Accused murderer describes Lawndale killing in court, saying 'I just got so mad.'
item.description:
Weeping and at times shouting on the witness stand, an Iraq war veteran described in court Friday how he stabbed his girlfriend to death in their Lawndale apartment during a fight when she decided to leave him and take their newborn daughter.

Tymarc Warren Jr., 28, whose defense for the Jan.
item.dc:creator: By Larry Altman, Staff Writer

media:content.media:description: Tymarc Warren's dad speaks about the case in video interview.

item.title: Man leaps to death from Torrance cliff
item.description:
A 26-year-old man jumped to his death Friday from a cliff in Torrance, police said.

The man plunged about 2 p.m. from the cliff known to locals as Bunker Hill near Hawthorne Boulevard and Via Valmonte, Torrance police Lt. Keith Fournier said.

Police found a suicide note.
item.dc:creator: By Larry Altman, Staff Writer

item.title: Redondo Beach man alleged to have pilfered $1.6 million in government fraud case
item.description:
A Los Angeles County probation officer, his former girlfriend and four other adults were charged Friday with allegedly operating an elaborate child care scam that cost taxpayers $1.6 million, according to prosecutors.

The six suspects are accused of conspiracy to commit grand theft, grand theft and multiple counts of perjury.
item.dc:creator: By Brian Charles, Staff Writer

item.title: Stolen 1960s-era LAPD policewoman badge returned to Cerritos woman
item.description:
When Cecilia Dominguez joined the Los Angeles Police Department in the late 1960s, women wore skirts and their badges designated them as "policewoman."

The badges changed in the early 1970s to the unisex "police officer," reflecting the growing ranks of female officers.
item.dc:creator: By Donna Littlejohn, Staff Writer

media:content.media:description: 0803_NWS_TDB-L-POLICEWOMAN-- 20130802 - San Pedro, CA --Daily Breeze Staff Photo: Robert Casillas / LANG --- Retired LAPD detective Cecilia Dominguez had her rare Policewoman badge stolen from the trunk of her car where it was kept during repairs to her home after a fire. The badge was recovered by undercover officers during drug raid and returned during a small ceremony at Harbor Division.

0803_NWS_TDB-L-POLICEWOMAN-- 20130802 - San Pedro, CA --Daily Breeze Staff Photo: Robert Casillas / LANG --- Retired LAPD detective Cecilia Dominguez had her rare Policewoman badge stolen from the trunk of her car where it was kept during repairs to her home after a fire. The badge was recovered by undercover officers during drug raid and returned during a small ceremony at Harbor Division.

item.title: More cases of West Nile discovered in Los Angeles County mosquitoes, birds
item.description:
Thirty-seven more mosquitoes and nine dead birds with West Nile virus were found in Los Angeles County, from the western San Fernando Valley to the South Bay, health officials said Friday.

The news came a day after county officials confirmed the area's first human death from West Nile virus this year -- a 78-year-old Carson man whose family said he died from the virus Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By City News Service

item.title: 'Sandman' drama in Carson will explore link between drugs and gangs
item.description:
Victory Outreach Church of Carson will present the drama "Sandman" at Scottsdale Town Hall at 6 p.m. Saturday in an effort to show how drugs increase gang activity in the community.

The drama will be presented with special music and food will be served outside of the hall, located at 23400 S.
item.dc:creator: By Sandy Gerety, Staff Writer

item.title: Jury asks for life sentence for Somali pirates who killed 4 Americans, including Marina del Rey couple
item.description:
NORFOLK, Va. -- A jury recommended Friday that three Somali pirates be sentenced to life in prison in the slayings of four Americans, including a Marina del Rey couple, aboard their yacht off the coast of Africa.

Prosecutors had sought the death penalty. But a federal jury in Norfolk, Va.
item.dc:creator: By Brock Vergakis, The Associated Press

media:content.media:description: Scott and Jean Adam

item.title: Two men, one shot by police officer, get prison for Gardena robbery
item.description:
| POLICE NEWS | BLOG: SOUTH BAY CRIME, COURT NEWS | FACEBOOK

Two men, including one shot by a Gardena police officer, have been sentenced to prison for holding up a 7-Eleven convenience store.

Jose Luis Ramirez, 22, received seven years in prison, and Luis Antonio Gutierrez, 22, received five years for the Jan.
item.dc:creator: By Larry Altman, Staff Writer

item.title: My Turn: Hawk encounter leaves lasting impression with Peninsula resident
item.description:
A Cooper's Hawk jumped off a branch and gracefully circled around, until a tiny version of itself appeared to fall out of the same tree, flapping away in an attempt to master the air and join the larger bird.

Eventually, the little wings worked and together the raptors headed into a canyon edging the nearby nature preserve.
item.dc:creator: by Laura Hines-Jurgens

media:content.media:description: Laura Hines-Jurgens: My Turn

item.title: Renee Moilanen: Liberate yourself by dumping that unneeded kid stuff
item.description:
When you live in a 900-square-foot apartment at the top of a steep flight of stairs, you become selective in the amount and type of stuff you accumulate.

More than once, I've stood in the middle of a store holding a doughnut maker or Mixmaster or oversized magazine rack and said to myself: Do I really want to drag this unwieldy box up the narrow staircase to my apartment? And if so, will I even have room to store it in cupboards already packed with necessities like plates, glasses and food?

My husband and I have transformed every square inch of the house into storage, including our bed, which flips up into a king-size bin packed with ski clothes and luggage.
item.dc:creator: by Renee Moilanen

item.title: Saturday's police log: Hawthorne, Lawndale and Gardena
item.description:
| POLICE NEWS | BLOG: SOUTH BAY CRIME, COURT NEWS | FACEBOOK

HAWTHORNE

New reports were not available for this week's log.

LAWNDALE

The Daily Breeze did not obtain reports for this week's log. Information about crime in areas patrolled by the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department, including links to maps of crime, is available on its website, http://sheriff.
item.dc:creator: By Stephanie Walton, Staff Writer

item.title: CD review: 'Down Fell the Doves' puts rich talents of Texas songwriter Amanda Shires on full display
item.description:
Texas native Amanda Shires began her musical career at age 15 playing fiddle in bands such as the post-Bob Wills Western swing Texas Playboys and, later, with respected songwriter Billy Joe Shaver.

Hats off to Shaver for encouraging her to nurture her songwriting talent, which -- happily -- has turned out to be prodigious.
item.dc:creator:
By Sam Gnerre
@samgnerre on Twitter

item.title: Two pit bulls fatally shot in attack on officers in Yucaipa
item.description:
YUCAIPA -- Two pit bulls were shot and killed Wednesday morning after charging at authorities responding to reports of a dog attack.

The shooting occurred in the backyard of a home in the 12200 block of 11th Street after authorities began to investigate a report of three large pit bulls attacking a homeowner's goats at the residence.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Hernandez, Staff Writer

item.title: Robert and Joyce Carlson of Redlands attend family reunion at Carlson Ranch in Missouri
item.description: Robert and Joyce Carlson of Redlands recently attended a family reunion at Carlson Ranch, 16 miles north of Mountain Grove, Mo. Dennis Carlson owns the ranch, which has 127 acres of pasture and timber. In the photo are, front row, from left, Hannah Carlson, Hawaii; Joey and Amy (Carlson) Barnett, San Antonio, Texas; Grace Carlson, who just graduated from the University of Colorado; Max Carlson, Hawaii; Andrew Wigfield, Irvine.
item.dc:creator: For the Redlands Daily Facts
